COLLEGE ADMISSIONS REQUIREMENTS FOR TRANSFER STUDENTS 


THIS MAJOR IS OFFERED BY THE COLLEGE OF LETTERS AND SCIENCE (L&S)


IMPORTANT information for students applying for admission to L&S for the fall 2025 application cycle and beyond


Completion of Essential Skills requirements (Reading & Composition, Quantitative Reasoning, and Foreign Language) or

Cal-GETC/IGETC will no longer be a requirement for admission; however, completion of either is strongly recommended

prior to enrollment at UC Berkeley to ensure timely degree progress. More information on new polices is available on

the L&S Transfer Student Applicants website. 


By the end of the spring term preceding fall enrollment at Berkeley, you must complete: 


1) The 7-course pattern (as found in the UC Transfer Admission Eligibility Courses Menu in ASSIST):

·   Two transferable courses in English composition;

·   One transferable course in mathematical concepts and quantitative reasoning;

·   Four transferable college courses chosen from at least two of the following subject areas:

o arts and humanities

o social and behavioral sciences

o physical and biological sciences


AND


2) Major Requirements: 

Follow the guidance on preparation for this major below. 


For more information on L&S General Education requirements:


For information on courses that will satisfy L&S General Education (Essential Skills and

Seven-Course Breadth) requirements from your community college complete the following steps:

  1. Go to "Search below for articulation agreements: Major, department, and campus-specific general education agreements”
  2. Click on the down arrow to select: Academic Year, Institution: UC Berkeley, and Agreements with Other Institutions: (Your CA Community College). 
  3. Click on “View Agreements”.
  4. Under “View Agreement by” select “General Education/Breadth”. 
  5. Click on the “General Education/Breadth” radio button, then click on “View Agreement”


Learn more from the UC Berkeley Office of Undergraduate Admission and specifically about transfer admission preparation. 


Review all available majors at UC Berkeley.

The department of Comparative Literature offers a wide variety of opportunities to explore and dive into the literary arts - literature, film, theater, music - across and within culture, time, language, genre, and theme. Comparative Literature majors take classes in our department and in other language/literature departments on campus.


Students of Comparative Literature: 

- develop their ability to read literary texts responsibly and critically, including through the lenses of culture, language, and context; 

- study one language literature in depth and another selectively; 

- acquire a broader sense of literary history and of literary traditions than the study of a single literature could furnish;

- explore the connections between writing and other pursuits; 

- acquaint themselves with some of the significant writings in theory of literature; 

- prepare themselves for the methodical investigation of issues involving more than one literature, language, and/or culture. 


Students interested in Comparative Literature must work in two languages and must complete language requirements prior to beginning study in another language. Second language work could be a second native or heritage language or a language studied prior to enrollment at Cal. It is possible to complete the degree in four semesters with only some prior language experience, however students should confirm language placement both with the Comparative Literature Undergraduate Major Advisor and with their intended language department. General language guidelines for Comparative Literature can be found here. 


This document describes the major requirements. Approved course lists are published every semester, including for summer sessions, and are published/cataloged on the right hand side of this page.


Comparative Literature undergraduates also have the opportunity to serve on the editorial board of the Comparative Literature Undergraduate Journal (CLUJ), a collection of literary analysis essays, and Vagabond, a multilingual literary magazine; and they can participate in organizing the entirely student-run Undergraduate Research Symposium.


PREPARATION FOR TRANSFER AT THE JUNIOR LEVEL 

Comparative Literature intended majors should have completed Reading and Composition coursework. Additionally, students must have or pursue adequate work in at least one secondary language, sufficient to qualify to take a minimum of two upper division literature courses in that language by the time of graduation.
